stripCallOut.text: Headline: Asset management company pays USD$12m to settle conflicts charges
Blackrock, a large asset management company, paid USD$12 million to settle charges of conflicts of interest due to the actions of one of its portfolio managers.

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission brought charges after it discovered that a broker who oversaw some Blackrock energy funds also founded a family-owned oil and gas company during the same time. The family company partnered with a coal company – and that same coal company’s shares were the largest holding in a fund the broker ran.

stripCallOut.text: Headline: Hospital board member personally fined $13,500
A board member of the New York City public hospital system was personally fined for conflicts discovered between his board role and his position at a medical school in Grenada.
The City Conflicts Board found that the doctor had wrongly used his board position to lobby city hospitals to increase the number of placements from students at the medical school he worked for.
Headline: JP Morgan pays USD$35m after giving compromised advice during deal
Investment giant JP Morgan paid USD$35 million to settle charges stemming from its actions during the sale of Good Technology to BlackBerry in late 2015.

Good Technology shareholders had charged that the company was sold below its market value and that JP Morgan pushed Good Technology into a sale because it wanted to win future investment banking business from BlackBerry. The court agreed, and awarded the shareholders a large judgment.
